prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to detect infall signature in optically thick (HCO+(J=4-3) and thin line (H13CO+(J=4-3). First, an inverse P Cygni profile needs sufficiently good velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s or so. Similary the systemic velocity can be determined with reasonable velocity resolution. In case that the line emission is stronger, we set the velocity to be 0.1 km/s. Further, CO set up with 0.4 km/s velocity resolution may enable us to identify presence of a molecular outflow.

The typical T Tauri Binary separation is 30 AU or so. In order to resolve the typical protobinary, 0".15 (30 AU at Lupus 3 at 200 pc) is required.
In line observations, the emission may be extended, so it is appropriate to lower angular resolution to 0".45 to lower the noise level in brightness temperature.
The disk size at protostellar phase is typically < 100 - 200 AU and thus we assume it to be 1".

Minimum detected flux density at 357 GHz is 15 mJy in Harris+12. We aim at detecting a secondary source weaker by a factor of 10, 1.5 mJy and thus the 1 sigma noise level is required to be 0.3 mJy at 5 sigma detection. As a result, we set the integration time to be 2 min to achieve this noise level at 357 GHz with 2 Pol and 4 GHz bandwidth
In line observations, the disk temperature around Class 0/I sources is expected to be 10-30 K. Our 2 minute integration gives 1 sigma noise level of 1 K in TB to sufficeintly detect inverse P-Cygni profile in HCO+ if we convolve 0".45 resolution with 0.4 km/s.

Our goal is to detect infall signature in optically thick (HCO+(J=4-3) and thin line (H13CO+(J=4-3). First, an inverse P Cygni profile needs sufficiently good velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s or so. Our goal is to detect infall signature in optically thick (HCO+(J=4-3) and thin line (H13CO+(J=4-3). First, an inverse P Cygni profile needs sufficiently good velocity resolution of 0.4 km/s or so. Similary the systemic velocity can be determined with reasonable velocity resolution. In case that the line emission is stronger, we set the velocity to be 0.1 km/s. Further, CO set up with 0.4 km/s velocity resolution may enable us to identify presence of a molecular outflow.

The typical T Tauri Binary separation is 30 AU or so. In order to resolve the typical protobinary, 0".15 (30 AU at Lupus 3 at 200 pc) is required.
In line observations, the emission may be extended, so it is appropriate to lower angular resolution to 0".45 to lower the noise level in brightness temperature.
The disk size at protostellar phase is typically < 100 - 200 AU and thus we assume it to be 1".

Minimum detected flux density at 357 GHz is 15 mJy in Harris+12. We aim at detecting a secondary source weaker by a factor of 10, 1.5 mJy and thus the 1 sigma noise level is required to be 0.3 mJy at 5 sigma detection. As a result, we set the integration time to be 2 min to achieve this noise level at 357 GHz with 2 Pol and 4 GHz bandwidth
In line observations, the disk temperature around Class 0/I sources is expected to be 10-30 K. Our 2 minute integration gives 1 sigma noise level of 1 K in TB to sufficeintly detect inverse P-Cygni profile in HCO+ if we convolve 0".45 resolution with 0.4 km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose continuum imaging of Class 0 and I protostars in Lupus in Band 7 with ALMA. The main purpose of continuum imaging is a proto-binary survey: to determine the frequency, separation, and flux ratio (disk mass ratio) of binaries at the protostellar stage in a nearby low-mass star-forming region. ALMAs high resolution, comparable to typical separations of known proto-binaries (0".15), and high sensitivity in the submillimetre allows us to conduct a first complete survey of low-mass proto-binaries in Lupus, complementing our Class II binary survey in Lupus at similar angular resolution to NACO/VLT. HCO+(4-3), H13CO+(4-3), and CO(3-2) data obtained simultaneously with the continuum data will reveal how infalling envelope and outflow characteristics vary with evolutionary stage. The results of these ALMA observations will provide very important constraints on theories of binary protostar formation and will identify interesting sources to be followed up in the future.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: This proposal is a revised Cycle 2 proposal (2013.1.00474.S). There are three differences. First, higher resolution is aimed to go down to 25 AU at Lupus 3 cloud (d=200 pc). Second, we emphasize detection of inverse P cygni profile suggestive of infalling motion. Third, we add one Class I source to the Cycle 2 target after revising our Lupus catalog. As a result, we need to take data even if our Cycle 2 high priority project is conducted.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales
ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
